g.text: Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
3.3. Location of Management of Patients with Emerging Infectious Diseases
A high proportion of all respondent groups felt that their workplaces were not well prepared to
care for patients with emerging infectious diseases, although many respondents indicated that they
The majority of respondents believed that patients with MERS-CoVand other emerging infectious
diseases should be managed in specialised centres, but a signiÔ¨Åcant proportion also agreed that general
hospitals also had a role in managing such patients. A minority indicated that patients with emerging
infectious diseases could be managed in primary healthcare clinics (Figure
Int. J. Environ. Res. Public Health
agreed that general hospitals also had a role in managing such patients. A minority indicated that
patients with emerging infectious diseases could be managed in primary healthcare clinics (Figure 2).
Opinions of the HCWs about the sites that should manage the MERS-CoV and other
3.4. Educational Needs about Emerging Infectious Diseases
It was noted that 45% of physicians, 53% of nurses and 61% of other HCWs in the study
perceive their knowledge about MERS-CoV, Ebola and others emerging infectious diseases to be
low, while 40% of them indicated that it was moderate and ‚â§7% indicated it was high (Figure 3).
As expected, the majority of the HCWs in the study (‚â•72.3%) indicated that that they are in
need for educational courses and training about the MERS-CoV, Ebola and other emerging
Perception of the HCWs about the level of their knowledge and the needs of educational
courses about MERS-CoV and other emerging infectious diseases.
